caseTitle: MALLAM ALI YUSUF ISSAH v. THE REPUBLIC
summary: Mallam Ali Yusuf Issah, former Minister of Youth and Sports, was convicted by the High Court for stealing and fraudulently causing a financial loss of $46,000 to the state under sections 124(1) and 179A(3)(a) of the Criminal Code, 1960. He received concurrent 4-year prison sentences on each count and was ordered to refund the amount or face an additional 2-year sentence. The Court of Appeal upheld the conviction but quashed the 2-year default sentence for non-refund. The Supreme Court dismissed his appeal, affirming that the evidence supported the conviction beyond reasonable doubt and that the trial did not violate his right to a fair trial under Article 19 of the Constitution. The court rejected claims of improper burden of proof, denial of adjournments, and unconstitutionality of the fast-track system, finding no miscarriage of justice.
citations: sections 124(1) and 179A(3)(a) of the Criminal Code, 1960 (Act 29)
Article 19 of the 1992 Constitution of Ghana
Section 31(1) and (2) of the Courts Act, 1993 (Act 459)
British Airways v. The Attorney General, [1996-97] SCGLR 547
rationaleHighlights: Conviction upheld due to sufficient prosecution evidence supporting guilt beyond reasonable doubt
Appellant failed to discharge burden of producing evidence to raise reasonable doubt on framing defence
Trial court's refusal of stay and adjournments did not infringe fair trial rights under Article 19
Court of Appeal correctly interpreted trial judge's comments on burden of proof
Sentences deemed not harsh given concurrent nature and gravity of offences
